title: 105_s602
content: The "Crime Control Act of 1997" is aimed at protecting personal security through tough Federal laws, including mandatory minimum prison sentences for violent crimes involving a firearm. Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include definitions for "crime of violence" and "drug trafficking crime" as offenses punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year. The amended Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, defines "crime of violence" and "drug trafficking crime" as offenses punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year, involving the manufacture, distribution, possession, cultivation, sale, or transfer of controlled substances or having a firearm readily available during the commission of the crime. The amended Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, defines "crime of violence" and "drug trafficking crime" as offenses punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year, involving the manufacture, distribution, possession, cultivation, sale, or transfer of controlled substances or having a firearm readily available during the commission of the crime. A person who, during a crime of violence or drug trafficking crime involving a firearm moved in interstate or foreign commerce, knowingly possesses a firearm, shall face additional penalties. The amended Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, imposes harsh penalties for possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. Penalties include a minimum of 10 years for possession, 20 years for discharging a firearm with intent to injure, and 30 years for possessing a machinegun or destructive device. Repeat offenders face even harsher penalties. Possessing a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking can lead to harsh penalties under Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code. Penalties include a minimum of 20 years for possession, 30 years for discharging a firearm, and life imprisonment for using a machinegun or destructive device. Repeat offenders face even harsher consequences. A person convicted of possessing or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking under Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, faces life imprisonment. No probation, suspension of sentence, or early release is allowed for such convictions. A person convicted of possessing or discharging a firearm during a crime of violence or drug trafficking under Section 924(c) of title 18, United States Code, faces life imprisonment without probation, suspension of sentence, or early release. This paragraph supplements State and local prosecutors' efforts in prosecuting crimes of violence and drug offenses, except for cases where a person acts in defense of a person or property during a crime committed by another person. The Attorney General shall defer to State or local prosecutors in prosecuting crimes of violence and drug trafficking under State law, without creating enforceable rights. The Crime Control Act of 1997 mandates prison work for all able-bodied federal inmates and prohibits luxury items like television, radio, telephone, and stereo in their cells.
